citeinfo.title: FY2000 Progress Report: Willamette Valley Wetlands: an evaluation of site connectivity and relative importance to wintering shorebirds

pubinfo.publish: USGS Forest and Rangeland Ecosystem Science Center

descript.abstract: The Willamette Valley of western Oregon constitutes a critical area where expanding human populations collide with the need for improved wetland quality and quantity. Efforts for wetland restoration have been carried out on a local scale, but there has been no systematic approach for evaluating the success of these efforts or how they should proceed in the future. In partnership with the Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Oregon Wetlands Joint Venture, and the National Shorebird Plan, we propose a joint effort to become more strategic in our Willamette Valley wetland conservation programs across agencies. We will examine the distribution and status of the Valley's wetlands using shorebirds as indicators of wetland connectivity. Our goal is to use this information to contribute to the emerging Willamette Valley Wetland Conservation Plan. The plan will include an overall strategy for acquisition, restoration, and conservation of critical wetlands as well as site-specific recommendations. During plan development, we will solicit advice from the numerous agencies involved in Willamette Valley wetland conservation. By the end of the project, we hope to have a mutually agreed upon, interagency working document for wetland conservation.
